Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear response of encapsulated contrast microbubbles for noninvasive blood pressure measurement

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1603639
PI: Sarkar, Kausik

Microbubbles are used routinely in medical diagnostics to enhance the contrast of ultrasound images. The microbubbles usually are encapsulated with lipids or proteins so that they persist when introduced into the blood stream. The hypothesis of this project is that the acoustic response of encapsulated microbubbles in the bloodstream can be separated from the acoustic response of surrounding tissue and can be used to measure the blood pressure in the small blood vessels of various organs. The project comprises experiments to measure the acoustic response of encapsulated microbubbles under varying ambient pressures, the development of a numerical model to help interpret the experimental data, and the formulation of a protocol for pressure estimation that will be tested in collaboration with physicians at Thomas Jefferson University who discovered that the acoustic response of encapsulated microbubbles depends on the local pressure. Results of the study could provide physicians with a new diagnostic tool to measure blood pressure throughout the body to enable early detection of disease in specific organs. The investigators will involve in the project students at all academic levels, including undergraduates from groups traditionally underrepresented in science and engineering.

This proposal builds on an observation made by clinicians at the Thomas Jefferson University that the subharmonic response from contrast microbubbles decreases with increasing ambient pressure. However, other experiments, including those by the project investigators, and models developed by the investigators suggest the subharmonic response may increase or decrease with ambient pressure. The goal of the project is to explain the apparent discrepancy, delineate regions of different behaviors, and determine how the subharmonic response depends on the pressure-dependent mechanical properties of encapsulated microbubbles. In collaboration with clinicians at Thomas Jefferson Medical Hospital, the investigators will synthesize lipid coated microbubbles and characterize their encapsulations using a nonlinear interfacial rheological model at different ambient pressures, investigate the pressure dependent nonlinear response from contrast microbubbles, and determine optimal material and excitation parameters for pressure estimation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long term goal of this project was to aid in developing a new imaging technology that would non-invasively determine organ-level blood pressure for safe accurate and early diagnosis of diseases such as cancer, portal hypertension. Current diagnosis of portal hypertension involves invasive procedures with risk of mortality and other complication. Our aim was to ultrasound imaging with injected tiny gas bubbles that would offer recognizable signature depending on local blood pressure in the vasculature.

 We have developed a novel setup to measure the acoustic responses of such microbubbles under pressurized conditions mimicking physiological conditions. We also developed our own Pegylated lipid coated microbubbles varying the coating chemistry. We investigated the effects of the coating on the bubble response. In collaboration with Professor Mallik in North Dakota State University, we also investigated a novel naonoparticle naturally secreted in the body, exosomes. We made them sensitive to ultrasound by processing them according to a specialized protocol developed by our team. For the first time such echogenic exosomes were developed and their efficacy demonstrated.  We also investigated vaporization of droplets of volatile liquid that can be used for producing microbubbles on demand from much smaller nanodroplets using external ultrasound signals.   

 We published eight journal papers and 2 peer reviewed conference proceeding papers. Students and the PI presented their research findings in many national and international conferences. Two students obtained their PhD working on this project. Currently, one PhD student is working on this project.
